ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual discussion section

Although this section was a live virtual lecture, an important component of the course was participation in breakout rooms in which students were asked to try to tackle problems on their own after learning material from the instructor.
Most classes were a live virtual lecture where material was explained and students could ask questions, followed by breakout rooms to practice questions uploaded to Canvas about this material.
None
live unrecorded lecture
Breakout rooms.
Each class period we broke up into breakout rooms to complete practice problems and students were called upon to share their answers/what they discussed in the breakout rooms.
No other mode
N/A
Live virtual lecture
textbook homework and office hours
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had taken Calculus II before this course, in high school, and done well. But compared to that class, I felt like I walked away from this course with a far greater understanding of how calculus works and of how to explain concepts in calculus to other students.
Calculus skills! But I definitely learned that I am not interested in taking any more calculus if I don't have to.

I learned how to evaluate integrals of all kinds, how to evaluate convergence of infinite series, and had a useful intro into parametric and polar functions. My main insight was that I will never be a science major.
I learned about series, integration, and polar and parametric graphs.
I learned the basics of single variable calculus.

I learned techniques for integration and how to evaluate infinite sequences and series. I also learned how to solve calculus problems with parametrics and polar coordinates. Overall, my problem solving skills also improved. I feel that I gained a better conceptual understanding of topics in this math class than I have in the past.
Calculus with a single variable
Integral calculus.
An introduction to single-variable calculus as applicable to science and economics, with an emphasis on integration, series and sequences.
I learned more about series, volumes, and integrals
I learned a variety of calculus skills such as series and sequences, volume calculations, integration, and more.
This course allowed me to refine and expand my knowledge of integration techniques and applications. It also encouraged collaboration among my peers.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think by far the greatest strength of this course was Itziar's approach to teaching. Unlike the other instructors I was exposed during review sessions, Itziar always came to class with a well-thought out, well-planned agenda for the day's lesson. But at the same time that she provided that structure, she pushed students to think for themselves by creating breakout rooms and asking us to solve difficult problems on our own before talking about them as a classa challenge that could be frustrating in the moment, but one that did a great job of preparing us for tests and getting us to really understand the material. The one big challenge of this course was waking up before 9:00 AM, especially as the semester dragged on, but that's neither here nor there.

The instructors were good about releasing and returning our homework grades with comments for about the first month of the semester, but then that stopped. I had no idea how much my homework grade actually would be helping my overall grade. Outside of that, I have no complaints about how the course was run, especially considering the online format. I think I just didn't really like the content. 

One thing I did really like was how my instructor in particular had guided notes we could fill in as we went through the lecture. I think it helped keep me engaged with the class being taught over Zoom.

Strengths: teaches fairly useful mathematical skills, problem sets are effective at practicing material and not too time-consuming. 
Weaknesses: Different instructors have wildly varying teaching skills, midterms didn't always perfectly align with course material, latter third of the course jumps between unrelated subjects to teach elementary skills in parametric and polar functions.
I think the breakout rooms during lecture worked really. They felt like a nice change of pace and allowed me to discuss and practice math with some of my classmates.
Very fast paced. But good lectures.

Strengths: my lecturer was very knowledgeable and explained concepts well. The peer tutoring was a great resource and the review sessions before tests were also very helpful. In terms of prepping for exams, the practice exams were also very valuable. The use of desmos was awesome for illustrating complex topics. 
Weaknesses: the exams were very conceptual so it would be nice to have more homework problems that were also more conceptual like those on the exam
This course did the best it could given the virtual learning situation, no cons that I can think of. I like how the professor gave us note worksheets to follow along the lecture with.

Strength - excellent professor (Itziar), fair grading policy
Weaknesses - some of the questions on PSETs were irrelevant, convoluted or fuzzy

Strengths: The schedule throughout the year was clear. The consistency of problem sets were nice and they helped to prepare for exams. The practice exams were also very helpful to prepare.

Weaknesses: n/a

Strengths: great exam prep material, well structured with lectures twice a week and a problem set due every week. The problem sets prepare you well for the exams. The breakout rooms were really great and really helped me to learn!
Weaknesses: sometimes I felt that the lectures went too fast. It would have been nice for the notes to be available after lecture to fill in the gaps of what I managed to scrawl.

The course was effective in focusing application and understanding of concepts rather than simply memorizing information. The instructor's lecture correlated well with the reading material. The course could have offered more resources for practice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms, as previously mentioned, were actually well-used and a great way of promoting student engagement.

Copied from Question #4: One thing I did really like was how my instructor in particular had guided notes we could fill in as we went through the lecture. I think it helped keep me engaged with the class being taught over Zoom.

Virtual lectures were perfectly fine, breakout rooms were effective if people in them actually spoke and worked collaboratively. 
Our instructor was in Europe during the semester so her office hours were less than convenient for many students. 
Some form of study groups organized by the instructors would have been helpful.
It would have been helpful to have recordings of the lectures.
The lectures worked. The review sessions are hard.

The breakout rooms were very valuable, especially since we got to stay with the same group all semester which allowed me to get to know my breakout roommates. The virtual lectures were effective and engaging. I appreciated that my lecturer posted the notes after class so that we could more easily access them.
Breakout rooms, while effective, were often far too long - professors mistimed the length of time we needed to complete a problem

The live lecture did a good job of explaining math concepts and the logic behind them. I wish homework had been more effective in helping me learn the material to a deeper extent. It didn't really help me think about the lesson further.

I think the practices in this course corresponded well with virtual learning. I think it is difficult to do any lectures via zoom, but my professor effectively did so. I also like the breakout rooms because they allow people to collaborate and talk about what they have learned.
The breakout rooms of three people were very helpful!

The course was effective in offering assistance with multiple sessions of peer tutoring and office hours in order to accommodate for different time zones. Engagement during group work was somewhat difficult due to the online learning format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're a pre-med and you're choosing between stats or this course, take stats!
If taught by Itziar or a few other instructors, yes. Otherwise: I've heard from friends and peers that it can be a tremendously challenging time.

Yes! If you're trying to figure out whether math, engineering, or another STEM subject might be your path, this is likely a prerequisite. If you're undecided about your particular course of study, it might help you narrow it down. For me personally, I learned that I wasn't interested in pursuing more calculus and higher level math, so I was able to eliminate engineering and math off of my potential majors list.
I would recommend this course to anybody who needs to take Calc II, especially social science majors. Definitely don't take this class for the intellectual stimulation.
If you like math, I would recommend this course.
Yes, I think it is a good level of challenge and rigor.
Yes, the course was well-organized and intellectually challenging
Not unless they need to take calculus; its not a necessary course otherwise
Yes absolutely, but if so, please take it ONLY with Professor Itziar.
Yes I would recommend this course to any student interested in getting a good foundation in calculus II concepts.
I would recommend this course to another student. I needed to take this in order to take other classes, but I ended up learning a lot.
Yes! If math is a requirement, this class is well structured with good feedback on tests and problem sets to help you improve and very helpful professors.
This course is necessary and essential to many Yale students pursuing a degree in the STEM field.
